Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Geometric Shape Deformation with Applications in Medicine

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
In spite of significant recent advances 3D computer graphics are still humbled when confronted with medical-grade requirements, so medical illustrators often continue to rely on 2D hand drawing. A fundamental challenge is that detailed geometric models and advanced nonlinear materials increase computational complexity, making them difficult to apply in real-time interactive applications. In this research, the PI will investigate an alternative approach based on geometric shape deformations rather than the processes which created them. He argues that intuitive shape deformation can be facilitated by guarantees of basic geometric properties such as smoothness and injectivity (no self-intersection). The key is to design algorithms that can do this quickly while providing the user with a small yet expressive set of adjustable controls to ensure an efficient interactive experience; the task of shape deformation techniques is to extrapolate this parsimonious, human manageable set of input controls into a full-scale 3D deformation field in a natural and predictable way. The PI's hypothesis is that this requirement can be formally expressed in terms of basic geometric properties. To this end, the PI will explore both direct (closed-form) and variational methods, because while direct methods excel in speed variational methods offer stronger guarantees and advanced geometric properties. In terms of direct methods, the PI will develop new ways to quickly blend certain groups of 3D transformations (e.g., with the help of new geometric algebraic structures). Transformation blending will be complemented by advanced influence weights that allow the user to explicitly control the resulting sparseness. In terms of variational methods, the PI will study deformation energies satisfying traditional properties such as rotation invariance but augmented with higher-order continuity and injectivity; here, the main challenge will be to find efficient numerical solutions for the underlying optimization problems. The PI believes it will prove possible to mitigate the inherent computational complexity of variational methods by suitably combining them with direct methods so as to cast some of the variational problems as convex optimizations, thereby opening the door to highly efficient convex solvers.

Broader Impacts: Shape deformation is relevant to architecture, computer aided design (CAD), and many areas of science and engineering, as well as to the entertainment industry. But this project has primarily been motivated by medical applications, inspired by requests from the PI's collaborators at The Children's Hospital of Philadelphia. Given the right tools, the classical field of hand drawn medical illustration will evolve into 3D animated medical atlases, setting new standards in medical education. Shape deformation techniques could ultimately contribute to clinical praxis, by facilitating diagnosis and pre-operative planning when treating conditions such as pathological skull deformities (craniosynostosis). And shape modeling tools in expert hands could help lower the radiation dose required in CT scanning, by applying new reconstruction methods that combine user input with template models and accurate surface scans (obtained with radiation-free methods such as laser scanning). The PI also will organize seminars and courses that bring together medical and engineering students, including members of underrepresented groups, thereby promoting interdisciplinary collaboration in both research and education.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our world is full of different shapes. For example, consider the shapes of the skulls. Human as well as animal skulls have similar shapes, but they also exhibit significant differences. In some cases, shape abnormalities convey serious underlying medical issues, e.g., “craniosynostosis” is a condition characterized by pathological skull deformities in children.


The problems of shapes and forms of biological structures intrigued scientists throughout history but only recently, we gained the distinct advantage of being able to use computers to represent and manipulate shapes digitally. Humans understand shapes by their brain, but computers require precise mathematical models. One of such models was the focus of this project: geometric shape deformation, or the mathematics of transforming one shape into another, such as the skulls of two different people.


Within this project, we started by tackling basic challenges, such as the representations of shape deformations. One particularly successful effort consisted in creating smooth building blocks of deformations (known as “bases” in mathematics). These bases have a number of uses, one of them is specifying displacements at given points of interests and automatically computing a corresponding deformation. This was previously done in simple domains, but our method works even in a complex domains, such as the shape of the skull. Another elementary task involved figuring out how to avoid self-overlaps in deformations; this is a counter-intuitive problem, because material such as clay can never self-overlap in the real world, no matter how much we deform them. However, self-overlaps are common in computer simulations, because digital models are not subject to the same constraints as real physical matter. We devised a new method based on mathematical optimization that is guaranteed to avoid self-overlaps in computer simulations of deformable objects. Sometimes it is important to consider the physical and dynamic nature of elastic objects in computer simulations. To this end, we developed a new fast physics-based simulation method called “Projective Dynamics,” outperforming many previous competing simulation methods.


The solutions of basic shape deformation problems served as stepping stones for applications focusing on specific shapes. In one such project, we considered biomechanical models of growth and developed a system which is capable of predicting the changes of shape in the human body, in particular as a result of hypertrophy or atrophy of muscle and fat tissues. We have studied this problem both on the entire body as a whole, as well as in the special case of the face. While biological growth occurs within one individual, shape deformation is also capable of relating shapes between different individuals, a process called “registration”. In particular, we have devised a new method for registering skull shapes between different individuals, taking into account not only the surface of the skull, but also its volume.


An important motivation for pursuing the geometric problems of shapes was our desire to better understand the problems of “craniosynostosis”, a medical condition manifesting itself as pathological skull deformities in children which may require surgical interventions in serious cases. We joined forces with a team of surgeons and set out on a mission to objectively quantify the severity of craniosynostosis. This is a difficult problem, because human skulls naturally exhibit a variety of different shapes and many of them do not pose any medical concerns. This is an ongoing research effort which will require collection of large amounts of data, their careful analysis and, ultimately, clinical validation. However, the results which we have obtained and published so far suggest that computers can potentially be more accurate than humans in evaluating the severity of craniosynostosis. This does not mean that the diagnostic work of clinicians should be fully automated. Instead, we aim to provide a new tool, a sophisticated “measuring tape”, which clinicians could use to make better informed and more objective decisions and treatment plans.
